meanings.definition: To formally accuse of or charge with a serious crime.
meanings.sent1: The prosecutor will indict the suspect for robbery.
meanings.sent2: The grand jury decided to indict the criminal for murder.
meanings.sent3: The detective jokingly said he would indict the cat for stealing treats.
meanings.sent4: Her eyes seemed to indict him of betrayal.
meanings.sent5: The evidence was enough to indict him beyond any doubt.

meanings.sent1: The teacher will indict the student's behavior in front of the class.
meanings.sent2: The media will indict the government's handling of the crisis.
meanings.sent3: She would often indict her own cooking skills with a smile.
meanings.sent4: His silence seemed to indict his guilt more than any words could.
meanings.sent5: The harsh words seemed to indict her character in everyone's eyes.
